Analogous concepts and similar terms.1: Cricket
Analogous concepts and similar terms.2: Baseball

Analogous concepts and similar terms.1: an innings (either singular or plural)
Analogous concepts and similar terms.2: a half-inning or side; innings is a plural term – but most commonly, one batting turn is called either the "top" or the "bottom" of an inning, depending on which team bats first or second

Analogous concepts and similar terms: player who delivers the ball to start play
Analogous concepts and similar terms.1: a bowler, who bowls
Analogous concepts and similar terms.2: a pitcher, who pitches

Analogous concepts and similar terms: player who strikes at the ball
Analogous concepts and similar terms.1: batsman (The term batter is used in women's cricket.) The batsman facing the bowler is the striker, the other is the non-striker
Analogous concepts and similar terms.2: batter (The term batsman is often used, however, in the phrase "hit batsman.")

Analogous concepts and similar terms.1: 22 yards (66 feet) or 20.1 metres (approx. 58 ft or 17.7 m between the bowler and batsman at delivery)
Analogous concepts and similar terms.2: 60 feet 6 inches or 18.4 m (approx. 58 ft or 17.7 m between pitcher and batter at delivery)

Analogous concepts and similar terms.1: wicket-keeper (or "keeper" for short)
Analogous concepts and similar terms.2: catcher

Analogous concepts and similar terms.1: flexible
Analogous concepts and similar terms.2: predetermined

Analogous concepts and similar terms.1: (batting) innings, knock, dig
Analogous concepts and similar terms.2: plate appearance, at-bat, ups

Analogous concepts and similar terms.1: (a.k.a. guard) bat held vertically, with the handle upwards, and the bottom edge on the ground
Analogous concepts and similar terms.2: bat held cocked in the air behind the head

Analogous concepts and similar terms.1: shot or stroke (The batsman need not run)
Analogous concepts and similar terms.2: hit – also shot, stroke, knock, etc. (The batter must run if the ball is hit into fair territory)

Analogous concepts and similar terms.1: batsman carries bat while running and uses it as an extension of his body
Analogous concepts and similar terms.2: batter drops bat after hitting and while running

Analogous concepts and similar terms.1: boundary: lines, ropes, fences, other objects, no physical marker (Law 19)
Analogous concepts and similar terms.2: fence, wall

Analogous concepts and similar terms: scoring over the boundary or fence
Analogous concepts and similar terms.1: runs are scored if the ball touches or lands over the boundary; six runs (six) if on the full, four runs (four) if on the bounce or along the ground. If a boundary is scored off a wide or no-ball the extra run is still added so it can also be either five or seven runs.
Analogous concepts and similar terms.2: home run if on the fly (and fair) – one, two, three, or four runs depending on the number of runners on base; automatic double ("ground-rule double") if on the bounce from fair territory – batter and any runners on base may advance only two bases; thus, only a maximum of two runs may be scored

Analogous concepts and similar terms: Hits inside the field result in...
Analogous concepts and similar terms.1: as many runs as the batsmen can complete. Normally between zero and three, but there is theoretically no upper limit in unusual circumstances such as misfields, overthrows or lost balls. If the ball strikes a piece of the fielding team's discarded equipment such as hats, helmets etc., an automatic five run penalty is awarded against the fielding side to the striking batsman.
Analogous concepts and similar terms.2: runners advancing, with possibility of one or more runners reaching home for a run.

Analogous concepts and similar terms: batsman scoring no runs in an innings
Analogous concepts and similar terms.1: duck. Known as a golden duck if out on the first ball faced or a diamond duck if out without facing a ball and/or out on the first ball of the team's innings. Scoring a duck in both innings of a first class match is known as a pair and the terms king pair or golden pair are used if both dismissals were golden ducks.
Analogous concepts and similar terms.2: struck out (common even for a skilled batter), "left stranded" (which occurs when a batter hits the ball and gets on base, but the team gets all out before he is able to score a run – something which doesn't happen in cricket except in the case of a "diamond duck" when a batsman is run out without having faced a ball)

Analogous concepts and similar terms: hitting the ball in a specific area
Analogous concepts and similar terms.1: placement
Analogous concepts and similar terms.2: place hitting

Analogous concepts and similar terms: hitting the ball high into the air, liable to being caught
Analogous concepts and similar terms.1: skyer (or skier), spooning it up, "scooping the ball", "flier"
Analogous concepts and similar terms.2: fly ball, pop fly, popup, "skying it"

Analogous concepts and similar terms.1: catch
Analogous concepts and similar terms.2: fly out or catch (see in flight)

Analogous concepts and similar terms.1: a wicket
Analogous concepts and similar terms.2: an out

Analogous concepts and similar terms.1: bowled, caught, leg before wicket, run out, stumped, hit wicket—or, very rarely: hit the ball twice, obstructing the field or timed out
Analogous concepts and similar terms.2: tag out, fly out, force out, strike out, interference (similar to obstructing the field in cricket, but more common)

Analogous concepts and similar terms.1: appeal to an umpire – a wicket cannot be given without an appeal from the fielding side, unless the batsman leaves the field on his own (Law 31).
Analogous concepts and similar terms.2: automatic – most outs are called immediately by umpires; some potential outs require an appeal play to be called but this is rare.

Analogous concepts and similar terms.1: leg break, off break, googly, doosra, leg cutter and off cutter change direction after bouncing. Often these will also drift while in the air. Topspinners dip downwards and bounce higher, arm-ball and flipper fly flatter and skid on. The away swing or outswinger curves away from batter in the air, the in swing or inswinger curves toward batter. Seam deliveries will also sometimes turn on the bounce.
Analogous concepts and similar terms.2: breaking balls curve in the air; the curveball/slider/cut fastball away from the pitching-hand side, the sinker, splitter, and forkball unexpectedly dip downwards (as can a curveball; see 12–6 curveball), the rare screwball bends toward pitching-hand side, as will the increasingly common circle change, and the unpredictable knuckleball which relies on atmosphere and wind can literally move in any direction, and even may corkscrew on its way to the plate

Analogous concepts and similar terms: a delivery not in a good hitting zone
Analogous concepts and similar terms.1: wide (and a penalty run can be awarded if the batsman is unable to reach the ball in his normal batting stance)
Analogous concepts and similar terms.2: ball

Analogous concepts and similar terms.1: misfield
Analogous concepts and similar terms.2: error

Analogous concepts and similar terms.1: wicket, pitch, deck or strip
Analogous concepts and similar terms.2: infield or diamond

Analogous concepts and similar terms.1: Assuming a right-handed batsman, the "Off side" is the side to his right, while the side to his left is called the "Leg side" (as that is the side closest to the batsman's legs) or sometimes the "On side". Reverse for a left-handed batsman.
Analogous concepts and similar terms.2: "Left field" is always to the batter's left and "right field" is always to the batter's right (when facing the pitcher), regardless of the side of the plate he hits from. The term "opposite field" in baseball is equivalent to "off side", as it is the side of the baseball field in front of the batter as he faces the pitcher.

Analogous concepts and similar terms.1: injured players can be replaced for fielding and running, not bowling, batting or keeping wicket except in the case of concussion (Law 2)
Analogous concepts and similar terms.2: players can be replaced in line-up for any reason; once removed they cannot return (except in certain youth leagues such as Little League which allow a "courtesy runner" for a pitcher, some recreational leagues and exhibition games, and in special rules such as designated hitter); baseball substitution rule was originally also only in case of injury; unlike cricket, the replacement could also bat

Analogous concepts and similar terms.1: "bouncer", "beamer" or sometimes "beamball" – umpire may warn or eject the bowler
Analogous concepts and similar terms.2: "beanball" – umpire may warn or eject the pitcher

Analogous concepts and similar terms: Words used in both sports, possibly with different meanings
Analogous concepts and similar terms.1: Words used in both sports, possibly with different meanings
Analogous concepts and similar terms.2: Words used in both sports, possibly with different meanings

Analogous concepts and similar terms.1: any legal delivery by the bowler
Analogous concepts and similar terms.2: a legal delivery not entering the strike zone nor swung at by the batter. If a batter receives four balls during one plate appearance, he is awarded a base on balls or walk.

Analogous concepts and similar terms.1: powerfully hit ball from the face of the bat, usually with the bat positioned vertically or close to vertically
Analogous concepts and similar terms.2: powerfully hit ball, often used to describe when the ball comes off the bat fast and flat "Line Drive" (could be a hit, or caught for an out)

Analogous concepts and similar terms.1: the area of the field less than 30 yards (27 m) from the pitch (basically oval in shape, marked by a restriction line in limited- overs cricket)
Analogous concepts and similar terms.2: the area of the field inside the grass line and immediately near the "diamond"; the "diamond" is the area inside the baselines, which are straight lines either drawn between bases (home plate to first – third to home plate) or imaginary (first to second and second to third); the "diamond" is thus a square 90 feet (27 m) on a side but is called such because of how it appears as seen from home plate.

Analogous concepts and similar terms.1: an innings is a period of batting, it can refer to that of a whole team, or an individual player
Analogous concepts and similar terms.2: an inning is one period of batting for each team (3 outs per half-inning)

Analogous concepts and similar terms.1: the "batting lineup" means the players who are regarded as strong batsmen. a "strong or long batting lineup" might mean 7 or 8 recognised batsmen.
Analogous concepts and similar terms.2: the players playing in a given game, particularly with respect to their batting order

Analogous concepts and similar terms.1: a batsman is "given out" by an umpire when he is dismissed in any of several ways. "outs" is never used.
Analogous concepts and similar terms.2: batters can be "out"; when there are three "outs" the half-inning is over; the term "retired" is also used.

Analogous concepts and similar terms.1: the area of the field more than 30 yards (27 m) from the pitch
Analogous concepts and similar terms.2: the fair-territory area outside the grass line

Analogous concepts and similar terms.1: batsman promoted up the batting order to score runs quickly in a one-day game (deliberately borrowed from the baseball term)
Analogous concepts and similar terms.2: substitute for another batter

Analogous concepts and similar terms.1: the prepared area in which where the ball is delivered to the batsman the area on the pitch in which the bowler bounces the ball
Analogous concepts and similar terms.2: the act of throwing the ball toward the batter

Analogous concepts and similar terms.1: Applies to an entire interval, such as an innings
Analogous concepts and similar terms.2: Applies to a single pitch.

Analogous concepts and similar terms.1: an aggressive shot hit with a horizontal bat towards the legside boundary, typically played to a short delivery
Analogous concepts and similar terms.2: similarly, to hit a pitch towards the side of the field closer to the hitter (left field for a right-handed hitter and vice versa)

Analogous concepts and similar terms.1: a batsman can stop batting part way through their innings (when the team is doing well, to give junior batsmen a chance to get experience – "retired out"; rarely or never in high-level matches), or "retire hurt" (this is usually due to injury (or being taken ill), in which case they have "retired not-out", and can resume play later in the team's innings.)
Analogous concepts and similar terms.2: to retire a batter means to get the batter out; when three outs are completed, ending the batting team's turn in an inning, the team on the field is said to have "retired the side"

Analogous concepts and similar terms.1: unit of scoring, achieved by the batsmen changing ends in one movement, or awarded for a boundary (4 or 6 runs), or for a penalty (1 to 5 runs)
Analogous concepts and similar terms.2: unit of scoring, achieved by a batter or pinch runner who safely reaches home plate after visiting first, second and third bases in succession, in up to four movements

Analogous concepts and similar terms.1: stroke which scores one run
Analogous concepts and similar terms.2: hit which allows the batter to advance to first base. It can score one run or more if runners are on base. A lone run in an inning can be called a "singleton".

Analogous concepts and similar terms.1: to leave the field when out, without waiting for the umpire's decision
Analogous concepts and similar terms.2: slang for a base on balls: to advance to first base after receiving four balls
